I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  capital  market 
development  and  reform  in  selected  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). The TA will help identify the required key market infrastructure as well 
as  the  legal  and  regulatory  frameworks  to  foster  long-term  development  financing  for 
governments  and  corporations.  This  phase  1  TA  will  support  Azerbaijan,  Mongolia,  and 
Uzbekistan. It will draw on lessons learned from the region’s varied experiences, focusing on local 
currency  government  and  corporate  bond  market  development.  A  phase  2  TA  project  is 
envisioned to deepen capital markets further and broaden outreach to other countries.
 
 
2.  The  TA  is  included  in  the  2021 Management-approved results-based  work  plan  of 
Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC). The TA is aligned with the 
following operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030: (i) addressing remaining poverty and 
reducing inequalities, (ii) accelerating progress in gender equality, (iii) strengthening governance 
and  institutional  capacity,  and  (iv)  fostering  regional  cooperation  and  integration.1  
It will support the expansion of deep, efficient, and diversified financial markets to meet long-term 
financing needs, enhance financial stability, and eventually enable sustainable infrastructure 
financing and socioeconomic development for DMCs.2
 
 
II.  ISSUES  
 
3.  Benefits of local capital markets. Developing deep and efficient local capital markets 
creates multiple benefits. Many Asian countries face a massive financing gap, especially for 
sustainable infrastructure. A well-functioning local capital market can help mobilize and allocate 
long-term local currency financing in more sustainable ways and with less macroeconomic risk, 
thereby contributing to a country’s economic growth and poverty reduction. The G20 recognizes 
that a well-developed local currency bond market protects against global capital flows; reduces 
reliance on foreign currency borrowings, which are subject to exchange rate risks; and allows 
bank and corporate balance sheets to adjust more smoothly to economic cycles, among others.3 
Liquid capital markets in local currency also improve domestic resource mobilization, diversify 
funding  sources,  enhance  financial  stability,  and  support  the  banking  system’s  maturity 
transformation functions. 
 
4.  Impact of COVID-19. The impact of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) underscores the 
need for enhanced debt management by developing efficient local capital markets. The COVID-
19 pandemic has triggered rising public expenditures and declining revenues, putting pressure 
on  government  financing  across  developing  countries.4  Underlying  issues  in  the  banking 
segment, such as asset quality deterioration and bank recapitalization, are expected to worsen 
under current economic conditions. Domestic government bond issuance can help countercyclical 
public spending, and corporate bond issuance can support the real economy, by supplementing 
the banking sector with much needed liquidity. 
 
 
1  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila;  
and ADB. Strategy 2030: Operational Plans.  
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 24 October 2020. 
3   ADB. 2019. Good Practices for Developing a Local Currency Bond Market: Lessons from the ASEAN+3 Asian Bond 
Markets Initiative. Manila. 
4  Fiscal deficits are estimated to reach 12.8% of gross domestic product in Azerbaijan, 5.3% in Mongolia, and 3.3% in 
Uzbekistan in 2020 (International Monetary Fund. World Economic Outlook Database, April 2020 Edition).

2 
5.  Lack of recognition of benefits of local capital markets. The benefits of efficient local 
capital markets are not widely recognized, which leaves many DMCs with undeveloped local 
capital markets. Despite their potential benefits, capital markets in many countries in the region 
are still nascent, inefficient, or not liquid. In 2019, outstanding government securities were 2.3% 
of  gross  domestic  product  in  Azerbaijan,5  32.1%  in  Mongolia,6  and  0.5%  in  Uzbekistan.7  
The absence of an active government bond market or even of a government issuance program 
of short maturity securities with limited trading (and the absence of a secondary market) prevents 
the establishment of a pricing benchmark, such as the yield curve, which is necessary for the 
development of corporate bond markets and other financial instruments (e.g., social, green, or 
impact bonds) (footnote 3).8 The high level of dollarization of these economies, which impedes 
bond market development, reflects volatile local currencies. 
 
6.  Local capital market development implementation strategy. Many DMCs do not have 
a well sequenced and coordinated local capital market development implementation strategy. 
Capital  market  development  involves  government  ownership  and  commitment—closely 
coordinating complex, separate activities to form the necessary ecosystem and macroeconomic 
conditions for effective capital market transactions. Understanding of the appropriate sequencing 
of milestone achievements and the role that each institution plays needs to be enhanced. Many 
countries also lack a strategic plan for capital market development and a forum for key agencies 
to coordinate their efforts. 
 
7.  Legal and regulatory framework. DMCs need to strengthen the legal and regulatory 
framework as well as effective market infrastructure to build and maintain well-functioning local 
capital  markets.  Capital  market  development  must  be  supported  by  laws  and  regulations 
(bankruptcy, tax, corporate governance, transparency, and disclosure standards) to attract a 
diversified  issuer  and  investor  base.  Market  infrastructure—such  as  an  exchange  system, 
depository system, valuation system, registration system, clearing system, and primary dealer 
system—is also needed to facilitate the smooth operation of the market. 
 
8.  Supply side. In the absence of an effective enabling framework, securities issuance 
becomes  too  costly  and  unviable  for  the  supply  side  of  the  capital  market  to  develop. 
Governments, financial institutions, and private companies use local currency bond markets to a 
very limited extent to raise capital. Contributing factors include lack of recognition of its benefits 
and low availability of capital market products; limited experience of the public and private sectors 
in communicating with investors; and weak corporate governance integrating best  practice 
accounting reporting and auditing standards to comply with the disclosure requirements of 
efficient capital markets. 
 
9.  Demand side. On the demand side, investment in capital market products is limited by 
insufficient local institutional investors and incentives to invest in high-risk bond markets. Pension 
funds are limited, and insurance companies and local savings and insurance markets are not well 
developed. No infrastructure, such as funds and trusts, is in place for indirect vehicles. Banks are 
the primary investors and hold their securities until maturity, which impedes the development of

a secondary market. Demand for securities is hampered by perceived high risks, lack of tax 
incentives, and the availability of other low-risk, high-yield financial products such as deposits and 
real  estate.  Further,  investors  do  not  have  information  based  on  standardized  accounting

10.  Lessons learned. This TA will draw on lessons learned from previous ADB projects 
related to capital market development and domestic resource mobilization.9 Previous projects 
have emphasized taking a long-term approach, adhering to appropriate sequencing of reforms, 
and enhancing market infrastructure to put in place a well-functioning capital market. Careful 
diagnostics and consultations, as well as enhanced coordination, are also necessary. Further, 
experience shows that the creation of a multi-stakeholder association can be a sustainable model 
for pursuing initiatives to develop the market.10 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: enabling environment for deep and efficient 
local currency bond markets improved (footnote 1). The TA will have the following outcome: 
capacity for local currency bond market development strengthened.11
 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  Output 1: Local capital market assessments completed. The TA will analyze the 
capital markets of Azerbaijan, Mongolia, and Uzbekistan.12 A review of existing finance sector 
and capital market diagnostics, plans, and strategies will be conducted under the TA which will 
lead to technical studies to determine the capital market development progress against the 
sequencing of milestone achievements and comparison with other countries. This will be achieved 
through stakeholder consultations with relevant public and private sector entities, at a proposed 
forum for interaction. Stakeholders will jointly establish and validate country-specific road maps 
and strategic market development implementation plans, to address the identified gaps and 
required policy recommendations and capacity building in legal and regulatory frameworks, 
effective market infrastructure, and market supply and demand mechanisms. 
 
13.  Output 2: Knowledge sharing events on capital market development conducted. 
Capacity development will be based on the key findings under output 1 and will focus on the 
identified gaps and agreed priorities for each country. It will also cover international best practices, 
including  success  factors  unique  to  the  respective  regions  in  terms  of  policies,  laws  and 
regulations,  infrastructure  and  information  technology  systems,  market  mechanisms,  and 
products. This will be carried out through specific webinars, workshops, study tours, and other 
capacity  building  activities  for  policymakers,  financial  authorities,  and  financial  market 
stakeholders.  Collaboration  with  the  International  Capital  Market  Association  and  other

4 
international institutions will be pursued to tap their expertise in bond market development and to 
facilitate sharing of experiences by other countries. 
 
14.  The TA will transfer knowledge and make policy recommendations to DMCs for the 
development of capital markets to support the operational priority areas of Strategy 2030. The 
basis for these recommendations will be the findings of the country assessments and technical 
studies, as well as lessons gathered in seminars, capacity building, and knowledge sharing 
events. 
 
15.  ADB’s value addition. This TA will leverage the experience and knowledge built by the 
ASEAN+3 Asian Bond Markets Initiative,13 and complement the ongoing efforts of ADB operations 
departments and other development organizations in the selected DMCs.14 The TA will contribute 
to the various ADB programs and projects to support the financial markets development strategies 
of the DMCs. SDCC will produce knowledge products for wider dissemination of innovative ideas 
and lessons through ADB Knowledge Events. Where possible, the TA will complement and 
supplement existing and proposed initiatives and activities. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and administered by ADB. The key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
17.  Eligible and ineligible expenditures. The Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund will finance operational expenses related to eligible proposals agreed upon by 
the Government of the Republic of Korea and ADB. It will not be used for (i) civil works, (ii) the 
procurement of large-scale equipment, (iii) permanent staffing costs, or (iv) the hiring of staff 
consultants. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will administer the TA. The Finance Sector Group under the Sector Advisory Service 
Cluster of ADB’s SDCC will implement the TA and carry out TA administration and supervision, 
implementation oversight, and communication with consultants and stakeholders in coordination 
with relevant sector and thematic groups and operations departments. Activities organized under 
the TA will include the organization and participation of ADB DMCs in virtual and face-to-face 
knowledge events, such as workshops and conferences. ADB staff involved with the TA may 
participate as resource persons in knowledge sharing events, which will include eliciting feedback 
and suggestions on improving the activities being implemented under the TA. Budget will also be 
allocated  for  (i)  representation  and  entertainment  expenses  during  knowledge  events,  and 
(ii) ADB  staff  to  provide  support  services  (travel  and  related  costs  for  secretarial  and 
administrative services) for TA implementation and administration. 
 
13 The Asian Bond Markets Initiative was launched in December 2002 by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
and the People’s Republic of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea – collectively known as ASEAN+3 – to develop 
local currency bond markets and promote regional financial cooperation and integration to strengthen financial 
stability and reduce the region’s vulnerability to the sudden reversal of capital flows. More information can be read in 
asianbondsonline.adb.org.  
14 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development is an active partner of the Government of Azerbaijan, while 
the US Treasury is an active partner of the Government of Uzbekistan. ADB support in Mongolia includes the 
development of a bond market guide and proposed banking industry TA that will conduct a midterm review of the 
government’s financial market development program. In Uzbekistan, a proposed Financial Markets Development 
Program includes policy actions on government bond market development.

5 
 
19.  Project implementation will utilize One ADB teams, comprising representatives of relevant 
departments such as regional departments, resident missions, the Private Sector Operations 
Department, the Treasury Department, and the Economics Research and Regional Cooperation 
Department.

21.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions.15 Individual consultants 
bring in-depth knowledge of the subject and extensive hands-on experience in dealing with 
businesses and governments in multiple geographies. Resource persons will also be engaged to 
contribute to the delivery of regional knowledge events under the TA. 
 
22.  Cofinancier requirements. The team will submit progress reports on a regular basis to 
the fund manager of the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund, and 
additional updates on project implementation, as necessary.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 
to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund 
for Supporting Capital Market Development and Reform in Developing Asia (Phase 1), and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
